clues.text: Balanchine's "Who Cares?" features the music of this other George, including "Fascinatin' Rhythm"
Choreographer Maurice Bejart called this Stravinsky ballet "The Phoenix Reborn from Ashes"
In a classic 1890 ballet, the fairy of the songbirds dances at the christening of this fairy-tale heroine
Let's have a conference to discuss ABT's 2016 ballet based on this Plato dialogue about love
"The Tale of the Stone Flower", this "Peter and the Wolf" composer's last ballet, tells the tale of Danila, a stone cutter
This Celtic who battled Wilt Chamberlain had a 22.5-rebound average & won 11 NBA titles in a 13-year career
After filing for divorce in 2011, this comic might have said, "Katy? Bar the door!"
Sweet Keri Russell was deliberately cast against type as a tough Soviet spy on this TV drama
In an Oscar-winning role, he went into Maximus Decimus Meridius overdrive
He's played Snake Plissken, Wyatt Earp & "the strongest man in the world"

rounds.comments: (Alex: The same two vowels in the middle of each correct response.)

clues.text: To sleep a bit longer; now hit the button!
A fowl enclosure
To swindle one out of sheep's wool
People get buzzed practicing apiculture, AKA this
This 4-letter name of a chief Canaanite god means "lord"
Always a popular lunch line item, the Iranian beluga type of this food can cost $10,000 for a pound
This Italian dish of garlic toast topped with tomatoes & olive oil tempts palates in the cafeteria
The students rave about this type of Wagyu steak from Hyogo Prefecture, so pale when raw it's almost white
Why, Lunchlady Doris, your version of this 2-word pricey boneless cut of beef from the tenderloin... mwah!
Using a broiler to caramelize a sugar topping on a chilled, stirred custard is key to this 2-word French dessert kids love!
In some versions of the myth, Uther had used this sword long before his son Arthur removes it from the stone
The mythical birthplace of this pre-Columbian people was Aztlan, the "White Land"
In Greek mythology rivers leading into this place include Cocytus, Phlegethon, Acheron & Styx
After drinking from the fountain of Mimir, he becomes the wisest Norse god
The ultimate night watchman, the mythical giant Argus has 100 of these
Cheers to you if you know that this potent potable derives its name from the Russian word for "water"
From the Middle Dutch word for "ship" comes this term for the captain of a small ship or boat
The name of this spirit is from the German for "rattle" & "ghost"
From the Arabic for "to make known", it's a tax imposed by a government on imported or exported goods
Bacteria comes from a Greek word meaning "small stick"; this related word goes back to the Greek for "small" & "life"
This association abbreviated ALA wants to eliminate tobacco use & improve air quality
The logo of this human rights watchdog features a candle surrounded by barbed wire
More than the title of a disco hit, it has 2,700 locations & 600,000 volunteers just in the United States
The organization of these bereaved mothers of armed service members dates back to 1928
The wife of an AA co-founder started this organization for families of problem drinkers
The White Rabbit is running late, leading to all kinds of trouble at the start of this 1865 book
He took 17 years to write his last novel, "Finnegans Wake"
A 2015 BBC poll of literary critics said the greatest British novel is this George Eliot work named for a town
This poet & typographic innovator wrote lines capturing childhood like "when the world is puddle-wonderful"
In the '60s this controversial novelist wrote journalistic works like "Miami and the Siege of Chicago"
A tip of the cap if you know that the Army's special forces are known by this name
Wisconsin's Fox River empties into it
In 2000 this punk-pop band issued "Warning"; in 2005 they put out "Bullet in a Bible"
"Sure as God made" these edibles, Cubs fans left some on Harry Caray's grave after the 2016 World Series
Sperry & Hutchinson were famous for these items that could be traded for all sorts of things
On this festive night in 1999, a new ball made of Waterford crystal made its descent in Times Square
Mr. T proudly says he's one of these, devoted to the person who brought him into the world
I'll do my best with what you gave me, but I "can't make a silk purse out of" one of these
On Aug. 3, 1980 Ronald Reagan said "I believe in" these & said the federal government had too much power
2-word term for one who defends an unpopular cause for the sake of argument

rounds.comments: (Alex: And finally, you'll love this one...)

clues.text: "Tomorrow"
"The Short And Straight Boulevard"
"Straighten And Whisper"
"Go Separately"
"You'll Shun The Moon"
Neptune High is named for a sea god; this title mystery solver who went there has a war god in her name
Played by Alexis Bledel, Rory on this Netflix show's "A Year in the Life" returned to Chilton Academy in 2016
"The Wonder Years" & "Freaks and Geeks" were set at schools named for this president with Scottish roots
On "King of the Hill", Bobby was chosen to be the mascot for the school named for this legendary NFL coach
Students learn spells & more at Brakebills, a school in this Syfy TV show based on Lev Grossman's books

rounds.text: Dirk Stikker, Dutch foreign minister 1948-1952, wrote, "Churchill's words won the war"; this American's "words won the peace"
